In celebration of fifteen years
of coeducation at the Johns
Hopkins University, two events
are scheduled for this Saturday.
November 15. Both events are
open to all, free of charge. From
7-9 p.m., an open forum officiated by Student Council President Mark Komisky will take
place in the L/V Room of Levering Hall, with the participation of
seven students from New York's
Columbia University. From 9-11,

entertainment with pastries and
international-styled coffees provided gratis.

cancelled "Weekend Celebration
of Coeducation," a two day event

The Coalition for a Free South
Africa claimed a "partial victory" Monday in its campaign
against South African apartheid
after Maryland National Bank

In a press release, Maryland
National Chairman Alan P.
Hoblitzell announced that the
bank would cut "direct wire
transfers of funds to or from
South Africa," but would continue to accept those wires
indirectly.
"We're delighted that the bank
has finally recognized its responsibility,'' said
Coalition
spokesman Patrick Bond, "but
we're going to continue our campaign against the bank because

other concerns have not yet been
met."
These concerns, he said, include the lack of assurance that
seven Maryland National directors will not use their positions on
the Hopkins Board of Trustees to
oppose divestment.
Bond said that the D.C. Student
Coalition Against Apartheid and
Racism (DC SCAR) had filed a
petition with the Federal Reserve
Board blocking the bank's request
to create an insurance and leasing subsidiary and "through that
action, the bank was forced to
meet with us."
Referring to the bank's directors, Bond said that at the
meeting, "we gave them hell."
Bond said that the ending of the

the business world in a wellcoordinated campaign and
achieve a real, tangible success."

Physicians are in a unique position to turn fact into fiction
because, he said,"We hear over

According to Stone, "Ordinary,
everyday things in our lives are
very important to a writer.''
Stone never had formal training in writing. He said that most
of his literary education was
"self-administered.- He said his
writing technique "begins usually
with the 3x5 cards- that he carries in his pocket. On these cards
he notes various comments,
books he wants to read and things
that he needs to do. When the
cards accumulate, he sits down
4nd looks through them to find
that "they've coalesced like iron
filings to a magnet."
Chance comments by patients
and coworkers led him into a new
literary genre—the short story.
Stone read from his works to
show the "commonalities of
literature and medicine." His
first selection was a short story
about a doctor's experience with
a burn victim. The patient was
severly burned and told the doctors that he had suffered his
wounds while rescuing a young
boy from a late-night fire in the
boy's home.
The patient's name was Robert.
The doctor in Stone's story
describes Robert's ravaged facial
skin as "a variably cooling recent
lava flow,'' To the doctor,
Robert's eyelids were his most
striking aspect: "They had the
look of complete terror. .. They
lent to his face the unmistakable
appearance of one who has seen
death and been changed by it."
Robert's condition worsened in
spite of all the doctor's efforts.
"We were trapped, and so was
Robert.- The doctors tried more
toxic- antibiotics and additional

skin grafts but Robert's kidneys
began to fail. "The raging fever
returned, he was going out in a
blaze, an inferno of infection."
On the day that Robert died,
"his heart had skipped, shuddered and stopped.- Afterwards
the doctors learned that Robert
was not a hero but an arsonist
who had set two fires and was
trapped between them. "His tale
about his heroism and saving the
boy was a lie,- said Stone.
This story reminded Stone of
his days in medical ethics class.
-I like to think knowing the truth
would not have changed our efforts to save him, but who
knows? Robert certainly didn't,"
he mused.
Stone hastened to add. "This
story is not in all of its elements
true. but in my head it's certainly true.- He concluded that
one function of turning fact into
fiction is to learn about oneself.
"The truth actually hinders you
in your writing.- he commented.
He agreed with Henry James'
theory that it is better not to know
the whole story "because it will
unhinge one's creativity. What
happens in the domain of the
mind is a wondrous kind of
thing," he continued.
Stone does not restrict his
writing to medical topics.
however. He read another story

Foot- which was "triggered by
a remark a patient made to me,Stone commented.

lives behind them. A fire alarm
sounded, tilling them with fear

Since they heard no commotion

Symposium Cents
The Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium
drew to a close last week with John Cardinal O'Connor presenting the final lecture on the Symposium topic, "Religion
and Politics: The Separation of Church
and State." In the wake of that address,
thoughts are already turning to the
future of the M.S.E. Symposium.
We're never ones to pass up an opportunity to get our two cents in, so allow
us a few reflections.
Before this year's lecture series
began, we predicted that it would be a
success. We argued at the time that the
well-balanced line-up of speakers capped with lectures by Pat Robertson and
Cardinal O'Connor, two nationally prominent leaders in American religious
circles, would create a Symposium of
which the community could be proud.
Our prediction, in hind-sight, seems to
have been fulfilled. Our compliments to
M.S.E. Symposium Chairmen Paul
Carliner and Zeid Radd.
Soon, the Student Council's Committee on Commmittees(COC), led by Student Council Vice-President Simran
Brara, will begin the search for next
year's co-chairmen and topic. We hope
the COC will be as successful in that
search as it was last year. A few suggestions may be helpful.
A good starting place for improving
the Symposium next year would be to
expand the scope of the series. In recent
years, there has been a trend towards
choosing topics of a highly political
nature. Arms control, terrorism, and the
dynamics of foreign policy have all been
addressed consecutively. This year's
topic of "Religion and Politics" was
something of a diversion, but remained
nevertheless highly political.
Next year, a completely different kind
of symposium topic—something that
doesn't sound like it was lifted directly
from the list of Poli Sci course offerings in the Circular—would be a
welcome relief.
Some appealing examples include:
(The Pen as a Sword: The Power of
the Press in a Free Society (a particularly appealing topic for us in the
business). Speakers could address the
role of the press in shaping the news,
the shortcomings and advantages of the
electronic media, the state of First Ammendment rights in the twentieth century, the psychological power of the
printed word in affecting attitudes,
etc. . . .
cThe Future of Medicine. With so
many pre-meds out and about, it's surprising this topic hasn't received more
attention in recent Symposiums.
Speakers could examine the implications of medical advances for society,
medical ethics, world health management, and national issues like health insurance, HMO's, socialized medicine,
and Medicare. With the Johns Hopkins
Medical Institutions only minutes away,
one of the world's foremost medical

resources is available (cheaply) for the
asking.
cAmerican Culture: Does It Exist?
We proposed this topic last year but remain intrigued by it. Is there a uniquely American culture? If so, how is it
transmitted. Does it possess its own
body of music literature, or film? What
is its relation to other cultures? The most
interesting aspect of this topic is the
fascinating array of speakers it could
draw. Leaders in fields from the arts to
the sciences and everything in between
could be represented.
In addition to expanding the scope of
the Symposium topic, there are some
tactical improvements that could be
made. Spreading the Symposium out
over a longer period, perhaps months,
would probably be a wise move for next
year's Symposium chairmen. Traditionally, the Symposium lectures have
been lumped together, usually within
the space of two or three weeks. The
idea has been that a concentrated Symposium is a unified Symposium.
Practicality, however, suggests that
this tradition should be abandonned.
Scheduling for most major speakers is
done months in advance. Frequently,
desirable lecturers are eliminated from
consideration simply because they are
not able to make the three or four dates
offered. Expanding the length of the
Symposium would give heavily booked potential speakers more flexibility in
arranging to attend the series. Consequently, "quality" speakers would be
more likely to attend.
A final improvement that next year's
chairmen would do well to make is to
continue the "Garrett Room Discussions"—an innovation created this year
by Carliner and Raad.
The Garrett Room Discussions, as
conceived by Carliner and Raad this
year, seem to be an answer to one of
the most challenging perennial problems
posed by the Symposium—how can one
attract spectators to lectures by little
known speakers? Since the Symposium
has only limited financial resources, it
frequently has relied upon little-known
lecturers to fill the void between one or
two principal speakers. Such lecturers
often attract miserably small audiences.
This year, however, the idea of teaming up speakers on the same evening in
a less formal environment seems to have
paid off. Not only was the idea greeted
receptively, judging from attendance,
but the dual lecture added considerable
depth to the analysis of the Symposium
topic.

Symposium Cents
The Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium
drew to a close last week with John Cardinal O'Connor presenting the final lecture on the Symposium topic, "Religion
and Politics: The Separation of Church
and State." In the wake of that address,
thoughts are already turning to the
future of the M.S.E. Symposium.
We're never ones to pass up an opportunity to get our two cents in, so allow
us a few reflections.
Before this year's lecture series
began, we predicted that it would be a
success. We argued at the time that the
well-balanced line-up of speakers capped with lectures by Pat Robertson and
Cardinal O'Connor, two nationally prominent leaders in American religious
circles, would create a Symposium of
which the community could be proud.
Our prediction, in hind-sight, seems to
have been fulfilled. Our compliments to
M.S.E. Symposium Chairmen Paul
Carliner and Zeid Radd.
Soon, the Student Council's Committee on Commmittees(COC), led by Student Council Vice-President Simran
Brara, will begin the search for next
year's co-chairmen and topic. We hope
the COC will be as successful in that
search as it was last year. A few suggestions may be helpful.
A good starting place for improving
the Symposium next year would be to
expand the scope of the series. In recent
years, there has been a trend towards
choosing topics of a highly political
nature. Arms control, terrorism, and the
dynamics of foreign policy have all been
addressed consecutively. This year's
topic of "Religion and Politics" was
something of a diversion, but remained
nevertheless highly political.
Next year, a completely different kind
of symposium topic—something that
doesn't sound like it was lifted directly
from the list of Poli Sci course offerings in the Circular—would be a
welcome relief.
Some appealing examples include:
(The Pen as a Sword: The Power of
the Press in a Free Society (a particularly appealing topic for us in the
business). Speakers could address the
role of the press in shaping the news,
the shortcomings and advantages of the
electronic media, the state of First Ammendment rights in the twentieth century, the psychological power of the
printed word in affecting attitudes,
etc. . . .
cThe Future of Medicine. With so
many pre-meds out and about, it's surprising this topic hasn't received more
attention in recent Symposiums.
Speakers could examine the implications of medical advances for society,
medical ethics, world health management, and national issues like health insurance, HMO's, socialized medicine,
and Medicare. With the Johns Hopkins
Medical Institutions only minutes away,
one of the world's foremost medical

resources is available (cheaply) for the
asking.
cAmerican Culture: Does It Exist?
We proposed this topic last year but remain intrigued by it. Is there a uniquely American culture? If so, how is it
transmitted. Does it possess its own
body of music literature, or film? What
is its relation to other cultures? The most
interesting aspect of this topic is the
fascinating array of speakers it could
draw. Leaders in fields from the arts to
the sciences and everything in between
could be represented.
In addition to expanding the scope of
the Symposium topic, there are some
tactical improvements that could be
made. Spreading the Symposium out
over a longer period, perhaps months,
would probably be a wise move for next
year's Symposium chairmen. Traditionally, the Symposium lectures have
been lumped together, usually within
the space of two or three weeks. The
idea has been that a concentrated Symposium is a unified Symposium.
Practicality, however, suggests that
this tradition should be abandonned.
Scheduling for most major speakers is
done months in advance. Frequently,
desirable lecturers are eliminated from
consideration simply because they are
not able to make the three or four dates
offered. Expanding the length of the
Symposium would give heavily booked potential speakers more flexibility in
arranging to attend the series. Consequently, "quality" speakers would be
more likely to attend.
A final improvement that next year's
chairmen would do well to make is to
continue the "Garrett Room Discussions"—an innovation created this year
by Carliner and Raad.
The Garrett Room Discussions, as
conceived by Carliner and Raad this
year, seem to be an answer to one of
the most challenging perennial problems
posed by the Symposium—how can one
attract spectators to lectures by little
known speakers? Since the Symposium
has only limited financial resources, it
frequently has relied upon little-known
lecturers to fill the void between one or
two principal speakers. Such lecturers
often attract miserably small audiences.
This year, however, the idea of teaming up speakers on the same evening in
a less formal environment seems to have
paid off. Not only was the idea greeted
receptively, judging from attendance,
but the dual lecture added considerable
depth to the analysis of the Symposium
topic.
When Brara and members of the
COC meet in upcoming weeks to begin
the selection process for next year's
Symposium Chairmen, they will be
making difficult decisions. We hope that
the COC will nevertheless have the
wherewithall and the good luck to select
a topic and chairmen at least as intriguing as this year's.
